Communication: Communication is the way of conveying needs, thoughts, pain and feelings to one another. it is an an attempt to be understood by others and understand them in return.

Successful communication helps us better understand people and situations. It helps us overcome diversities, build trust and respect, and create conditions for sharing creative ideas and solving problems.

Although communication itself seems simple, often when we try to establish communication with others, there is always a chance for lack of understanding that might cause conflicts and frustrations in personal or professional life in relation with other people
Important: Listen to what you are being told.
Understand cultural influence to people's communication
Know your patient, it helps you understand them more
Show interest in what is being said.
Remain calm and be friendly as possible
sight: Don't Shout, They can't see not deaf
Describe the position of food in their plate and on the table, remember they cannot see.
Explain in detail what you are about to do.
Avoid whispering as most of the people with sight impairments depend on their hearing.
Speech: Be patient, don't rush the patient.
Use word charts/flash cards if the patient prefers it.
Disorientated: Give the correct information to try and orientate the patient.
Make sure the patient  is comfortable with the surroundings.
Hearing: Make sure that the patient can see your face when you talk, since they mostly rely on lip-reading.
Speak loud enough, but don't shout.
Be patient, repeat yourself if necessary.
stroke: * They think of what to say and how to say it.
* They attempt to hear and understand other people.
* They have a challenge moving mouth muscles to talk
Stroke attack part of your brain and damages it. If the damage occurs in the part that is responsible for speech or language, you may have problems communicating.
problems: - May get mixed up with words, forgeting names.

HadStroke: - Do not force them to say a word just because they got it right the previous time.
- Always keep them on the subject at hand, avoid them going off course with a conversation.
- They may draw or write what they want to tell you.
- Understand they not doing it on purpose.
- Encourage them to communicate in any way possible.
- Ask simple questions so that they can can just answer yes or no, nod or shake head.

- Join a club e.g support groups.

Asthma: Asthma is a sickness of the airways of the lungs that makes it hard to breath. These things might happen if you have asthma
- There's a tight feeling in your chest and you may make wheezing or whistling noises when breathing.
- Cough a lot at night and after doing exercises
If someone has an asthma attack, this is what you should
* Help them get out their inhaler and take their meds.
* Make a person to sit down, not lie down
* Make sire no one is smoking nearby
If the person is still struggling to breath after 5 minutes, call an ambulance. A serious attack is very dangerous and needs immediate medical attention.
Tract: Urinary tract infection (UTI) is an infection of the bladder or the tubes that carry urine from the bladder (ureters). Females get these infections more than males because the female uterine tubes are shorter than males, so it is easier for the bacteria to reach the bladder.
SignAndSymptoms: - Patient complains of pain when padding urine.
- Often feel like going to the toilet but may pass only a little urine each time.
- Urine my smell bad and look cloudy.
UrineHealth: - Females can get UTI from germs in feaces. Girls should be taught to wipe from the vagina towards the anus (front to back) when using the toilet to avoid germs entering the vagina.
- Keep genital area clean, but do not use perfumed soap, bubble baths or bath oils to the bath water.
HeartAttack: It is usually suspected when a patients has severe chest pains. The pains can be located across the chest or by the left sode of the chest, running down the left arm. The pain may also go into the neck, jaw or back. Patient may experience nausea, Vomiting, sweating, dizziness and shortness of breath. People usually confuse a heart atack with indigestion, as symptoms may be similar. A doctor must investigate any chest pain that is not relieved by antacids like Eno or repeated attacks of chest pains.
Epilepsy: This is a tendency to fits and seizures which are caused by a brief disturbance in the elctrical activity of the brain . The effect is that of an electrical storm in the brain. Do not be frightened when you see somebody having a fit. You need to keep calm and prevent anyone from rushing to the fitting person. There is very little you can do.
Never hold them down to stop the convulsions.
Never give them anything to eat or drink during the fit.
Do not call an ambulance, unless one fit follows another without patient regaining consciousness in between.
hepatits: It is an infectious disease that affects the liver, causing it to become inflamed. In severe cases, hepatitis can result in permanet liver damage.
Hepatitis A - is spread through infected food abd is the most common type. incubation period is 3-6 weeks and recovery takes 6 weeks.
Hepatitis B - is spread by contract with infected blood or intimate contact with an infected person. It is the most dangerous. Intravenous drug users are at high risk. It also take months to recover.
Hepatitis C - is the least severe but is becoming more common.It's also transmitted through infected blood- blood transfusions are the most common cause
Cataract: * It is a condition in which a part of the eye becomes cloudy.

The clouded part of the lens is also called blindness when the cloudiness covers a large area,is dense or is at the center of the lens. Some cataracts cause little to no loss of vision. Most cataracts result from aging. If a caract causes enough loss of vision, then that lens is removed during surgery. The patient must wear singlasses or contact lenses to see well. In many cases, surgeons replace the clouded lenses with intraocular lens.
Alzheimer: Alzheimer is a disorer of the brain that causes loss of memory and progressive mental deterioration. (Alois Alzheimer, a german neurologist first described it in 1906) it is age related, the older a person gets, the more likely for it to occur. People in their 40s and 50s can have it, though it is very rare. it is not part of normal ageing.
* Loss of ability to speak, function or understand.
* They don't care how they look and may refuse to bath.
* Suspicious of other people, and may accuse them of stealing or hiding things.
* Getting lost in familiar places like their own neighborhood.
PRKINSON: Parkinson's syndrome is a condition where there is a decrease in the levels of hormone dopamine and this leads to a chemical imbalance with typical symptoms. it is chronic, progressive and affects the nervous system. it affects the area of the brain that controls movement and balance.
A brain disorder that leads to shaking stiffiness and difficulty with walking, balance & coordination.
Weight loss due to metabolic increased activity caused by tremors and rigidity.
CONSTIPATION: Constipation is defined as having a bowel movemnet less than three times per week. With Constipation, stools are usually hard, dry, small in size and diffucult to eliminate. Some may find it painful to have a bowel movement and often experience bloating and sensation of a full bowel.
Eat well balanced, high fibre diet. (BEans, bran, whole grain, fresh fruits and vegetables).
Set aside time for breakfast, lunch and undisturbed time in the toilet.
DIABETES: It is a disease in which the body's ability to produce or respond tot he hormone insulin is impaired, resulting in abnormal metablism of carbohydrates and eleveted levels of glucose in the blood.

If the body is not producing enough insulin (TYPE1) or it is ineffective (TYPE2), glucose is not able to enter your cells and it consequently builds up/accumulates in your blood. Eventually the glucose enters your urine,
Wounds or cuts that won't heal.
Always balance your food intake with medication and activity.
DIABETESFOOD: Nerve damage - high blood glucose levels damage the nerves over time. Patients may lose feeling of their own feet and legs. Symptoms include numbness of legs or feet, tingling sensation in the legs and inability to feel your feet at all. This causes injuries from pressure since trauma goes unnoticed.
Poor circulation - reduced blood flow in the legs and feet results in too little oxygen and nutrients reaching the feet, causing injured feet to heal slowly or not at all.

Infection - diabetic patients are prone to infections and are less able to fight off infection due to weakened immune system. This often leads to ulceration of skin and tissue, due to late infection detection.

Foot deformities - flat feet, hammer toes, bunions can cause lesions in diabetics due to poor circulation and neuropathy (weakness and pain from nerve damage), lesions such as corns, calluses, blisters or ulcers are a result and can lead to serious infections, even to other parts of the foot.
Redness or swelling of foot or ankle
Change in size of foot or ankle
Skin color changes - blue, red, or black discolouration.
Corns and calluses with skin discolouration.
CANCER: Cancer develops when cells in a part of the body begin to grow out of control. All cancer types start because of out-of-control abnormal cells. The cancer cells do not die. They out live the normal cells and continue to form new abnormal cells.

Cancer usually forms as a tumor, except for leukemia that forms in the blood and circulate to other tissues where they grow.Not all tumors are cancerous. Benign (non-cancerous) tumors do not spread and are not life threatening.
Smoking can cause cancers of the lungs, mouth, throat and some other organs.Radiation and sunburns could cause skin cancer.
- Bowel habits - chronic constipation diarrhea and change in stool size can be a sign of colon cancer.
- Painful urination, blood in the urine could be sign of prostate cancer.
- Sores that do not heal, esp. in the mouth
- Lump in the breast other parts of the body. Esp. glands and other soft tissues.
- Indegistion or trouble swallowing. (cancer of the esophagus, stomach or throat cancer)
- Recent change in wart or mole; color , size or shape
- Nagging cough or hoarseness maybe a sign of larynx r thyroid cancer.

ISCEMIC STROKE - happens when the artery leading the brain becomes blocked by a blood clot anf circulation is obstruced.
HEMORRHAIC - stroke happens when the brain blood vessel is raptured/torn.

TUBERCULOSIS: It is chronic infectious disease caused by mycivacterium Tuberculosis. It mostly affects the lungs, limbs, glands, the spine, the brain and the kidneys.
Symptoms :
* Always stay calm
* Loss of weight
* Feeling very tired and weakness of the body
* Fever
* Sweating at night even when it's cold
* Coughing for more than 2-3 weeks, and not responding to antibiotics
* Blood stained sputum
* Chest pain
* Breathlessness
How TB is diagnosed
* A person should visit a clinic or doctor ASAP, where they will be examined
* Sputum may be collected and sent to the laboratory to check for any TB bacteria
* Chest x-rays may also be used
* Blood samples may also be tested for the bacteria
If the patient is diagnosed with TB, their family members also need to be tested since it is a contagious disease
Treatment:
* Patient needs to take the treatment for six months
* If they did not finish the course, the TTB will advance to MDR_TB (multi-drug resistant TB) which will require 18 months of treatment
Things to do while on TB treatment
* Continue taking care of yourself and those around you.
* Eat enough healthy food to stay health and flight the sickness.
* Maintain a healthy weight.
* Get plenty of rest and fresh air.
* When better, ask your healthcare worker about exercises you can do
* TB will stop being infectious after a few days of taking treatment, you may return to work.
When cured: On completion of the 6-9months period, it is essential that follow-up x-rays be taken. Sputum must once again be sent to the lab to verify complete healing.
BODYCARE: Hygiene is the recipe for healthy living. A healthy body always houses a healthy spirit.
HANDWASHING
INDEPENDENT PATIENTS
It is the duty of the Advanced Caregiver to motivate patients to waash their bodies, wash hands before and after meals, as well as after using the toilet.
You must also ensure that the washing oof hands has been done properly; check if hands and nails are clean and you must see that soap and a dry towel are available
DEPENDENT PATIENTS

The Advanced Caregiver must take care of the frail. Provide soap, dish, towel and water for them if they can still wash for themselves. If they are no longer able to wash their hands, do it using the toilet. You must ensure that washing is done properly, that hands and nails are washed properly
COMPLICATIONS FOR NOT WASHING HANDS
Dirty hands and nails are a source of bacteria, which cause infections
COMPLICATIONS FOR NOT WASHING HANDS
* Always wash hands with soap and water. water alone won't kill micro-organisms.
* Don't let water run continuously, close in between procedure.
* Use fresh water for every patient who is unable to wash themselves.
* Care not to splash water on the floor, you or the patient can slip and fall. Besides, it's unhygienic
* Keep soap dry when not in use.
* Moist skin is a source of germs.
* Do not share towels
Always throw dirty water in a sliice, not small basin in the bathroom.
Steps of social hand washing :
Wet hands wiith water
Close Tap
Apply soap
Now wash hands thoroughly, between fingers and approximately 5cm higher up from the wrist.
Rinse
Dry hands well with a clean dry towel
Discard paper towel in a dustbin
Wash your hands regularly, before and after procedure
WHEN TO USE SOCIAL HAND WASHING

After making each bed/handling linen.
 Before eating 
 Before and after contact with a patient ,
 when hands are visible dirty, 
 After the toilet, 
 After blowing your nose
